initial_story:
The winner of a Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, tournament has been stripped of his title after allegations of inappropriate behaviour.

Yan Chenglong has also been accused of cheating by using a communication device analogous to anal beads.

The 48-year-old has been stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) says it's impossible to prove accusations of cheating.

Xiangqi has been hugely popular across Asia for hundreds of years.

According to the CXA, Mr Yan started drinking with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national tournament held on the Chinese island of Hainan last week.

He then defecated in the hotel bath in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals", said the CXA statement.

The CXA was forced to address rumours circulating online that Mr Yan had cheated using anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Yan engaged in cheating via 'anal beads' as speculated on social media," the CXA said.

As punishment for bad behaviour, Mr Yan was stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Yan was forfeiting, but Xiangqi tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.
stories:
The incident has sparked a heated debate on social media, with some users expressing shock and disappointment at Yan's behavior, while others have criticized the CXA for what they perceive as an overreaction.

"Cheating or not, Yan's behavior is disgusting and unacceptable," said one user on Weibo, China's popular microblogging platform. "He doesn't deserve to be a Xiangqi player."

However, others have pointed out that the CXA's inability to prove the allegations of cheating raises questions about the fairness of the punishment. "If there's no concrete evidence, how can they ban him for a year?" asked another user. "This is a witch-hunt."

The CXA has defended its decision, stating that the ban is not solely based on the cheating allegations, but also on Yan's "unacceptable behavior" that violated public order and good morals.

Meanwhile, the search for a new Xiangqi King is underway, with the CXA announcing that a new tournament will be held in the coming months to determine Yan's successor. As the controversy surrounding Yan's disqualification continues to make headlines, the world of Xiangqi awaits a new champion to restore honor and dignity to the ancient game.

The debate has even caught the attention of prominent figures in the Xiangqi community, who are divided on the issue. Some have praised the CXA for taking a stand against cheating, while others argue that a year-long ban is too severe a punishment without solid proof.

In the midst of the controversy, Yan has remained silent, leaving his fans and critics to speculate on his next move. Many are wondering if he will appeal the decision or if he will accept the ban and fade from the spotlight.

As the community awaits more information, the CXA is facing increasing pressure to provide concrete evidence to back up their claims of cheating. Some are calling for an independent investigation, while others are demanding transparency and accountability from the organization.

Amidst the chaos, one thing is clear - the world of Xiangqi will never be the same again. The incident has exposed deep-seated issues within the community and has forced a reckoning that will likely have far-reaching consequences.

Only time will tell how this saga will ultimately play out, but for now, the search for a new Xiangqi King continues, and the ancient game's legacy hangs in the balance.

Amidst all the uncertainty and speculation, one thing is clear - the Xiangqi world will never be the same again. The scandal has exposed a deep divide within the community, and its outcome will likely set a precedent for future cases of alleged cheating.
